options.D: Three if it is long enough

questions.explanation: Only one person should be working on a ladder, although another person may be footing it, for extra stability.

questions.question: Ladders should be set at a slope of approximately:
Why should aluminium ladders be kept away from wet lime or cement?

options.B: The ladder may become statically charged

questions.explanation: Aluminium can corrode in certain situations, notably if in prolonged contact with lime or cement.

questions.question: Before being used, a ladder should be inspected:
questions.explanation: The user needs to be satisfied that the ladder is in a safe condition before using it.

questions.question: Ladders should be:

options.C: Tied or footed AND at the right angle AND in good condition

questions.explanation: All the measures listed are required to reduce the risk of falls.

questions.question: A ladder giving access to a scaffold can generally be safely used, provided that:

options.A: The foot of the ladder is firmly wedged
options.B: It does not move when you climb up it
options.C: Any broken rungs are clearly marked
options.D: It is tied and extends at least 1 metre above the platform

questions.explanation: Access ladders should extend at least 1 metre above the landing point to provide a safe handhold.

questions.question: What is the ideal angle for a ladder against a wall and floor?

options.A: One metre up for every metre out from the wall
options.B: One metre up for every two metres out from the wall
options.C: Two metres up for every metre out from the wall
options.D: Four metres up for every metre out from the wall

questions.explanation: The correct angle for a ladder is 75 degrees, which can be judged using the angle indicator marked on the stiles of some ladders or using the 1 in 4 rule.

questions.question: The rung of a wooden ladder has started to split, what should you do?

options.A: Do not use it, tell your supervisor
options.D: Jump on it to see if it holds your weight

questions.explanation: It is essential that supervisors are aware of faulty or damaged equipment.

questions.question: Ladders should not be painted because:

options.B: The paint will make them slippery to use
options.C: The paint may not be suitable on metal parts of the ladder
options.D: The paint may cover a defect or damaged part of the ladder

questions.question: When can you work from a ladder?

options.A: For short periods and then only if it is safe to do so
options.D: When not being used for access

questions.explanation: Ladders are primarily means of access, not workplaces. They can be worked from, but only if the use of other, more suitable, work equipment is not appropriate and the task is of low risk and of short duration.

questions.question: When working above public areas, what should be considered?

options.D: Keeping the areas open to the public

questions.explanation: There is a significant risk to the public from falling materials, if this is not considered before and during work.

questions.question: A scaffold tower must be erected by:

options.B: The hire company who supply it

questions.explanation: There are a number of organizations that provide training for the safe erection and use of scaffold towers.

questions.question: What is the minimum height of the top guard-rail of a scaffold above the edge from which someone is liable to fall?
questions.explanation: This is a requirement of the Work at Height Regulations 2005.

questions.question: A working platform used for construction work, and from which a person could fall 2 metres or more, must not be used unless it has been inspected (and a report is subsequently prepared) by a competent person:
questions.explanation: Under these specific circumstances a report is required to be prepared by the competent person and given to the person for whom the inspection was done (e.g. the site manager). This is in addition to the more general requirement to inspect equipment for work at height: prior to use in that position (or site if it is mobile); following exceptional circumstances (e.g. high winds); and at suitable intervals.

questions.question: On a mobile elevating work platform, what should you attach your safety harness to?

options.A: A secure anchorage point inside the platform
options.B: A strong part of the structure you are working on

questions.explanation: The priority is to stay within the platform (which is the safest place) and in any event you cannot be sure of the strength of other fixtures.

questions.question: You have been asked to operate a cherry-picker (mobile elevated work platform) when it is very windy. What should your FIRST consideration be?

options.A: Wear a safety harness and clip it to the structure that you are working on
options.B: Does the wind-speed make it unsafe to use the machine
options.C: Wear an extra layer of clothing to keep warm
options.D: Tie all light-weight objects to the hand-rails of the basket

questions.explanation: The priority in safety is eliminating risk at source in this case by not working in dangerous conditions rather than trying to stay safe by using protective equipment.

questions.question: If you have to work at height and it is not possible to erect a scaffold, or use any other type of working platform or mobile elevating work platform, then you should:

options.A: Work without fall protection, provided you have a mate with you
options.B: Wear a harness and lanyard at all times
options.C: Work without fall protection, provided the weather is not too windy
options.D: Work without fall protection at all times when no one else is about

questions.explanation: The harness will greatly reduce the likelihood of injury if you fall.

questions.question: When working on a roof that has fragile, clear-plastic panels, what is the best way of preventing falls through the panels?

options.A: Make sure that everyone is told where the panels are and to avoid treading on them
options.B: Cover the fragile panels with a strong material and secure the covers to stop them being dislodged
options.C: Remove the panels carefully to leave an open space.
options.D: It shouldn't be necessary to do anything, everyone knows the dangers

questions.explanation: Protection from falling through openings and fragile roof lights can be provided by barriers or with covers which can be secured or labelled with a warning.

questions.question: When working on a roof that has fragile, clear-plastic panels, what is the best way of preventing falls through the panels?

options.A: It is safe to walk on the purlins
options.B: Walk straight across the roof to where you need to get to
options.C: As long as you avoid any fragile areas it is safe
options.D: Crawling boards should always be used

questions.explanation: Fragile roofs must be made safe to work on, before work commences.

questions.question: Half the deaths on construction sites are caused by which one of the following?
questions.explanation: This is shown by HSE statistics.

questions.question: What should you do if your work activity requires you to wear a full body safety harness and one is not available?

options.A: Make a harness from items found on site
options.B: Carry on working and hope that everything will be alright
options.C: Borrow a harness from a colleague
options.D: Stop work immediately and tell your supervisor that you do not have the correct PPE

questions.explanation: Always advise the supervisor if you do not have the correct PPE.

questions.question: Under what circumstances do the Work at Height Regulations permit a stepladder to be used on site?

options.C: Provided you can't fall 2 metres or more
options.D: Only when a risk assessment shows that safer alternatives have been ruled out and the task is of low risk and of short duration

questions.explanation: The WAH Regulations have not banned the use of ladders or stepladders, but they should be used sensibly.

questions.question: What is the best method of securing a ladder?

options.A: Tying it to a suitable point
options.B: Using an effective ladder stability device
options.C: Wedging the ladder (e.g. against a wall)

questions.explanation: Tying the ladder is the safest option, making sure both stiles are tied.

questions.question: Of the following, which is the POOREST method of securing a ladder?

options.A: Securing the base of the ladder

questions.explanation: Footing a ladder is the last resort and should be avoided. Other more suitable access equipment should be used where practicable.

questions.question: Prior to moving a mobile tower scaffold, the platform height should reduced to a maximum of:
questions.explanation: This figure is quoted in guidance published by the HSE and PASMA. Checks should also be made that there are no obstructions overhead, the ground is firm, level and free from potholes, it is not too windy and there are no people or materials on the tower.

questions.question: What do the letters SWL stand for?
questions.explanation: Machinery and accessories for lifting loads should be clearly marked to indicate their safe working loads.

questions.question: Who should operate plant and equipment on site?

options.A: Only people over 18 years of age
options.C: An employee holding a full driving licence

questions.explanation: Never operate plant or equipment unless you have been trained and are authorised to do so.

questions.question: What hazard is created when the head of a cold chisel mushrooms?
questions.explanation: This question is looking for the hazard, which is the situation that can cause harm to people.

questions.question: Any damaged equipment must be:

options.D: Locked up so no one can use it

questions.explanation: It is essential that supervisors are aware of faulty or damaged equipment.

questions.question: The electric drill you are about to use has a faulty on/off switch. What action should you take?

options.B: Find another machine and carry on working
options.C: Remove it from use and tell your supervisor
options.D: Tape the switch on to keep it running and carry on working

questions.explanation: It is essential that supervisors are aware of faulty or damaged equipment.

questions.question: The power hand tool you are about to use has burn marks visible on the cable. What should you do?

options.A: Tape over the affected area and continue
options.B: Tell your supervisor about the defect and do not use the tool
options.C: Obtain another machine and carry on, but don't tell anyone
options.D: Carry on and get the job done

questions.explanation: It is essential that supervisors are aware of faulty or damaged equipment.

questions.question: Your supervisor asks you to use a powered hand-tool which has a rotating blade. You notice that the guard is missing from the blade. What do you do?

options.A: Use the tool anyway, you haven't had an accident with it before
options.B: Remove it from use and tell your supervisor
options.C: Try to make an improvised guard yourself
options.D: Contact the manufacturer of the tool

questions.explanation: It is essential that supervisors are aware of faulty or damaged equipment.

questions.question: Hand and power tools must be:

options.A: The best that you can buy
options.D: Suitable for the task and regularly inspected

questions.explanation: Tools must not create a risk to the user or others. This means they must be suitable and kept in good condition. This requires inspection before use.

questions.question: When should visual checks of portable hand-held equipment be made by the user?
questions.explanation: The user needs to be satisfied that the tool has no obvious defect before use.

questions.question: What precaution should you take before adjusting an electrical tool?

options.A: Check the lead is not twisted or knotted
options.B: Wear safety footwear with steel toe caps
options.D: Wear the correct personal protective equipment

questions.explanation: Do not adjust tools which could still be live or operate.

questions.question: An electric drill is to be used. Before use, who should carry out a check on the tool?
questions.explanation: The user needs to be satisfied that the tool has no obvious defect before use.

questions.question: What action should you take if an electric drill cuts out while you are using it?

options.B: Put it back into the tool box
options.C: Switch the power off and on
options.D: Remove it from use and tell your supervisor

questions.explanation: The drill may be faulty. If so, tell your supervisor and remove the drill from service.

questions.question: If an electric drill gives off blue smoke from the motor, you should:

options.C: Switch it off and report it

questions.explanation: Defective electric hand tools must not be used. Stop what you are doing and inform your supervisor.

questions.question: How often should user (visual) checks be carried out on portable electrical equipment?
questions.explanation: All items of portable electrical equipment should be visually checked for safety by the user before being put into use.

questions.question: What is the preferred nominal voltage for portable hand lamps for general use on construction sites?
questions.explanation: 110 volt reduced low voltage systems are strongly preferred for the supply to such equipment.

questions.question: What is the preferred nominal voltage for portable hand tools on construction sites?
questions.explanation: 110 volt reduced low voltage systems are strongly preferred for the supply to such equipment.

questions.question: What is the preferred nominal voltage for local lighting up to 2 kW on construction sites?
questions.explanation: 110 volt reduced low voltage systems are strongly preferred for the supply to such equipment.

questions.question: What is the recommended maximum voltage for portable hand lamps when working in confined or damp locations?
questions.explanation: Where the environment is damp, or restricting and conductive, the magnitude of any electric shock will be higher than under normal conditions. Hand lamps in such locations should therefore be supplied from a SELV (separated extra-low voltage) system, i.e. having a maximum voltage of 50 volts and which is electrically separated from earth.

questions.question: If you only have a mains voltage (230 V) hand drill and you want to use it on a construction site which only has yellow (110 V) socket-outlets, what should you do?

options.A: Use a transformer to boost the voltage
options.B: Cut the plug off and fit a yellow one instead
options.C: Obtain a 110 V drill or a cordless one for the work
options.D: Make up an extension cable with a yellow plug on one end and a standard socket on the other end

questions.explanation: Electrical equipment must not be modified or operated at voltages other than their design voltage.

questions.question: What is most commonly used to reduce 230 volts to 110 volts on site?
questions.explanation: A transformer, usually coloured yellow, will transform 230 volts (mains voltage) down to a relatively safe 110 volts.

questions.question: When using an extension cable reel, which of the following statements is correct?

options.A: Leave as much as possible coiled up on the reel
options.C: Do not exceed the reeled or unreeled rating as appropriate

questions.explanation: The rating of a partially unreeled extension cable is much lower than when fully unreeled. Overheating of the cable will occur if the rating is exceeded. Care should also be taken to prevent extension cables becoming a tripping hazard.

questions.question: If an extension cable is to be run across a site road, what action should you take?

options.B: Place a rubber protection ramp over it and put up a sign stating Ramp Ahead
options.C: Don't do anything to protect the cable
options.D: Lay the cable over wooden boards

questions.explanation: It is essential that the cable is protected from damage caused by passing traffic. A sign will warn road traffic of the ramp.

questions.question: To operate a powered hand tool you must be:
questions.explanation: There are no general age restrictions in legislation relating to the use of work equipment. Any person using work equipment. however, must be competent to do so, which will require initial and refresher training.

questions.question: If you are about to use a power tool and discover the guard is missing, you should:

options.A: Make up a temporary guard yourself
options.B: Use the tool but try to work quickly
options.C: Not use the tool until a proper guard has been fitted
options.D: Use the tool but work carefully and slowly

questions.explanation: Visual checks should be carried out before using equipment. Any faults should be reported immediately and rectified before use.

questions.question: Why may a confined space be dangerous to work in?

options.A: There may not be sufficient working space
options.B: Air in the space may be unbreathable due to poisonous gas
options.C: Temperature and poor ventilation may affect the worker

questions.explanation: There can be a range of hazards associated with confined spaces, and these can include all of those mentioned.

questions.question: What must be considered first when planning to carry out work in a confined space?

options.A: Has the job been priced properly
options.B: Have the correct tools been arranged
options.D: Can the work be done from the outside

questions.explanation: Working outside will remove the risks of working in the confined space.

questions.question: When working in a confined space, such as a sewer, what danger may occur?

options.C: Not enough time for the job to be done

questions.explanation: Sewer gases can be inflammable and suffocating.

questions.question: To determine the safety of the atmosphere in an excavation, which of the following is essential.

options.C: Only entering for a short period to enable a quick escape

questions.explanation: Use a suitable detector. Many dangerous gases have no smell and cannot be seen. Workers can be overcome in seconds in dangerous atmospheres.

questions.question: Before entering an excavation to start work, it must first be:
questions.explanation: Excavation work is hazardous. A competent person, knowledgeable about how to reduce risks, notably from collapse of the walls, must inspect the excavation first.

questions.question: What is the purpose of using a permit to work system?

options.A: To ensure the job is carried out by the quickest method
options.B: To help ensure a safe system of work
options.C: To ensure that the client will pay for the work
options.D: To enable tools and equipment to be properly checked before the commencement of work

questions.explanation: A permit to work is a written system used to control certain types of hazardous work. They allow work to start only when site procedures have been clarified.

questions.question: Why may young people be more at risk on site?

options.A: There is no specific legislation applying to them
options.B: They are usually left to work alone to gain experience
options.C: There is no requirement to provide PPE to young people
options.D: They are inexperienced and may not recognise danger

questions.explanation: Health and Safety guidance lists young people as often being at particular risk , due to their lack of practical experience.

questions.question: You have to enter a manhole in which you know there are toxic gases. You have all the PPE but there does not appear to be a rescue plan in place. What should you do?

options.A: Just get on and do the job, it will probably be alright
options.B: Plan to carry out the job in short bursts
options.C: Do not enter the manhole until a rescue plan and rescue equipment are in place
options.D: Ask your mate to stand-by at the top of the manhole with a length of rope

questions.explanation: A rescue plan must be in place before anyone enters a confined space. This is one of the requirements of the Confined Spaces Regulations 1997.

questions.question: You have to enter a manhole in which you believe there could be toxic gases. You have not been provided with any Respiratory Protective Equipment (RPE). What should you do?

options.A: Tell your supervisor that you will need RPE, and if necessary, training in confined space working
options.B: Sniff the atmosphere in the manhole to see if you can smell harmful gases
options.C: Look into the manhole to see if you can see any harmful gases
options.D: Just get on with the job, and accept the risks

questions.explanation: An employer must provide all necessary personal protective equipment and respiratory protective equipment when an employee is required to enter a confined space. This is one of the requirements of the Confined Spaces Regulations 1997.

questions.question: While digging a trench, you uncover a length of yellow marker tape at a depth of about 150mm. What does the presence of the marker tape mean?

options.A: The area has a high water-table and precautions must be taken to prevent an in-rush of water
options.B: There is a buried electrical cable and further excavation must be carried out with care
options.C: There is contaminated soil below the level of the marker tape and all excavation must stop
options.D: The excavation has reached a depth where the sides must now be supported

questions.explanation: The coloured tape indicates that there are buried services below the route of the tape.

questions.question: A Cable Avoidance Tool (C.A.T.) and a Genny (generator) can be used successfully to locate underground cables by whom:
questions.explanation: Equipment used to locate buried services must only be used by people who have been trained to use it.

questions.question: When exposing underground power cables, which method of excavation should you use?

options.A: A 360 degree excavator with rubber tyres

questions.explanation: Hand-held power tools and mechanical excavators should not be used too close to underground services and hand digging should be carried out with care.

questions.question: When do special precautions need to be taken when working near overhead electric power lines?

options.A: Only if cranes etc. are being used
options.B: Only if someone could touch a line with their bare hands
options.C: Only if plant has to pass under the lines
options.D: Whenever work areas will be near or beneath the lines

questions.explanation: Actual contact with a power line is not necessary to result in an electric shock as a close approach may allow flashover to occur. HSE publication GS6 gives advice on procedures to avoid such danger.

questions.question: When working alone:

options.A: Make sure someone responsible knows where you are
options.B: You can do away with protective equipment
options.C: Don't bother anyone if you have a problem, always sort it out yourself
options.D: Wear headphones, it will make the day go more quickly

questions.explanation: Employees should adhere to safe working arrangements put in place by their employer. When working alone, such arrangements should include informing a responsible person of your location periodically.

questions.question: You have to walk across a site several times a day, but have to dodge a lot of site traffic. The first thing you should do is:

options.B: Walk around the edges of the site to keep out of the way
options.C: Tell your supervisor about the danger
options.D: Jump on the back of a vehicle if you can, it's safer than walking

questions.explanation: Pedestrian routes should have been set up to keep people and vehicles apart, so inform your employer if the system is not working. Don't hitch rides on vehicles unless safe seating is provided.

questions.question: A mobile plant operator can let you ride in the machine:

options.A: If you have a long way to go
options.C: If it is designed to carry passengers

questions.explanation: Don't hitch rides on vehicles unless safe seating is provided.

questions.question: In accordance with the Electricity at Work regulations, when considering whether to work live a responsible person should:
questions.explanation: To identify and assess the risks involved and the methods of controlling them.

questions.question: The normal procedure for working on electrical equipment should be which one of the following?
questions.explanation: Dead working should be considered as the norm and work on or near live conductors should rarely be permitted.

questions.question: Test instruments used for working on electrical systems should:
questions.explanation: To protect the user from electric shock whilst using the instrument. i.e. handling the probes.

questions.question: Under the Electricity at Work Regulations, live working is considered:

options.C: Only to be allowed in exceptional circumstances

questions.explanation: Extra controls must be employed, including training, supervision and use of suitable tools and protective equipment.

questions.question: Which of the following would you use to replace the fuse in a plug if fuses were NOT available?
questions.explanation: A fuse is often the main safety device in an electrical circuit. A blown fuse must only be replaced by a fuse of the correct type and rating.

questions.question: To prove a circuit or equipment is dead after isolation what is the FIRST activity in the sequence of events?

options.A: Make sure equipment is not working
options.C: Check that the voltage detector is working on a proving device, known live source or in built test feature

questions.explanation: This will prove that that the voltage detector (such as a two-pole voltage detector or proprietary test lamp) is working, i.e. indicating voltage.

questions.question: The nominal single phase voltage in the UK is?
questions.explanation: This is the nominal voltage for public electricity supply systems within Europe.

questions.question: When is live working permissible?

options.A: When the person carrying out the work is a competent person
options.B: When it is unreasonable in all circumstances for the equipment to be made dead and suitable precautions are taken
options.C: When the means of isolation cannot be identified
options.D: When the person working on the equipment is wearing rubber gloves

questions.explanation: This is a requirement under r.14 of the EAW Regulations. However, it does not mean that live working is then safe.

questions.question: Which of the following is NOT a requirement of low voltage safe isolation practice?

options.A: Ensuring that the correct point of isolation is identified
options.B: The person carrying out the work is issued with insulating gloves
options.C: A caution notice should be applied at the point of isolation
options.D: The conductors are proved to be dead at the point of work

questions.explanation: Safe isolation practice refers to dead working. The use of insulating gloves will generally only be applicable to live working.

questions.question: The specific effects on the human body of a major electric shock are one of the following:
The lowest level of electrical current which can harm the human body is normally measured in:
questions.explanation: Research has shown that a person is in serious danger of a fatal electric shock at. or above, approximately 30 milliamps.

questions.question: With regard to the effect of electrical current on the human body, one of the following is correct:

options.A: A 6 amp circuit breaker should prevent a person receiving a fatal electric shock
options.B: A 3 amp fuse should prevent a person receiving a fatal electric shock
options.C: A 30 mA Residual Current Device (RCD) should prevent a person receiving a fatal electric shock
options.D: A 5 amp rewireable fuse should prevent a person receiving a fatal electric shock

questions.explanation: An RCD is a mechanical switching device intended to cause the opening of the contacts when the residual current attains a given value under specified conditions.

questions.question: Where mains voltage is used to supply portable equipment on a construction site, what additional protection is required?
questions.explanation: Reduced low voltage systems (e.g. 110 volt centre point earthed) are strongly preferred in such circumstances. Where only mains voltage (230 V) equipment is available, however, a 30 mA RCD will give additional protection against fatal electric shock.

questions.question: What colour cable USUALLY signifies 110 volt power supply on site?
questions.explanation: Yellow is the usual colour of cables, socket outlets, plugs and transformers etc which are used with a 110 volt supply.

questions.question: A portable electric generator on site has two power outlets, 110 volts and 230 volts. What colour would the 110 volt outlet be?
questions.explanation: Yellow is the usual colour of cables, socket outlets, plugs and transformers etc which are used with a 110 volt supply.

questions.question: Where there is no local means of isolation for equipment or circuits to be worked on, which of the following is the preferred method of isolation?

options.A: Use a suitable device such as a circuit breaker
options.B: Isolation of the individual circuit breaker or fuse
options.C: Pulling out the distributor's cut-out fuse
options.D: Disconnecting the individual circuit from the DB

questions.explanation: Isolating the whole installation or distribution board is the safest method.

questions.question: What action should you take if a workmate gets an electric shock?

options.B: Dial 999 and ask for the fire brigade
options.C: Cut off the power and call for help
options.D: Try to pull them to safety

questions.explanation: If you can switch the power off, the electric hazard will be removed. First aid assistance will then probably be required. Do not touch someone who is still in contact with live electrical cables as you could also receive an electric shock.

questions.question: A residual current device is designed to operate in the event of one of the following:
questions.explanation: An RCD provides additional protection against the risk of electric shock.

questions.question: Electrical installations on construction sites should be periodically inspected and tested:
questions.explanation: Three monthly inspections of construction site installations are recommended in IET Guidance Note 3.

questions.question: The maximum AC voltage which the human body can withstand without long term physiological effects in dry conditions is:
questions.explanation: Regarded as a non-fatal voltage level.

questions.question: Which of the following statements is true with regard to the dangers of electricity?

options.A: Electricity is perfectly safe so long as you wear cotton gloves
options.B: Electricity is only dangerous if you are not wearing wellington boots
options.C: Electricity is only dangerous in wet weather
options.D: Electricity is dangerous at any time because you cannot tell by looking at a cable whether or not it is live

questions.explanation: The features which make electricity so dangerous are that you cannot see, hear or smell it. It can give you a very unpleasant surprise. Always assume that cables are live.

questions.question: What is the most serious effect that electric shock can have if you come into contact with a live part?

options.A: The electric current can cause a slight tingling in the fingers
options.B: The electric current can cause burn marks on the fingers
options.C: The electric current can cause the heart to stop, resulting in death
options.D: The electric current can cause the finger muscles to twitch

questions.explanation: Contact with live electrical parts can be fatal. If you do not know otherwise, always assume that electrical parts are live.

questions.question: Your job involves you working near to hanging electrical cables which have bare ends. What should you do?

options.A: Touch the cables to see if they are live
options.B: Carry on working, as there shouldn't be a problem
options.C: Inform your supervisor and keep well away
options.D: Attempt to push the cables back into the ceiling void so that you can start work

questions.explanation: You must always assume that exposed cables are live until you know they are not. Contact with live electrical cables can kill.

questions.question: For all live working activities it is necessary to:

options.A: Carry out a risk assessment as required by the EAW Regulations.

questions.question: An electrical Permit to Work is primarily a statement that:

options.A: Someone else has taken responsibility for the work
options.B: The circuit or equipment is live
options.C: Certain instructions need to be followed
options.D: The circuit or equipment has been isolated and is safe to work on

questions.explanation: Permits to work describe the procedures that prevent a major hazard, such as electricity or moving machinery, from causing harm, usually by isolation to effectively ensure (in the case of electricity) dead working with no chance of it going live.

questions.question: The probes of voltage detectors and test instruments used on electrical systems should be:

options.C: Shaped or have barriers to prevent finger contact with the tips

questions.explanation: In addition, to protect against damage by overcurrent whilst in use, the probes or instrument should incorporate suitable high breaking capacity (hbc) fuses with a low current rating (usually not exceeding 500 mA). or current-limiting resistors.

questions.question: Which of the following does the Electricity at Work (EAW) regulations apply to?

options.A: All persons engaged for work purposes

questions.explanation: The EAW Regulations impose duties on employers, employees and the self employed.

questions.question: The Electricity at Work Regulations require that:

options.A: Persons working with electricity must have the appropriate level of knowledge and experience
options.B: A training course is necessary before anyone can work with electricity
options.C: Only electricians can work with electricity
options.D: Anyone supervised can work with electricity

questions.explanation: Competency is a requirement of r.16 of the EAW Regulations.

questions.question: The Electricity at Work Regulations apply to:
questions.explanation: The EAW Regulations cover the safe use of electricity in work activities, irrespective of voltage.

questions.question: Which of the following should be used to prove a circuit or equipment is dead after isolation?

options.A: A lamp holder with a length of flex attached
options.B: A proprietary test lamp or two-pole voltage detector

questions.explanation: Accident history has shown that using incorrectly set multimeters or makeshift devices for voltage detection has often caused accidents. The use of non-contact voltage indicators (voltage sticks) is also not advised as the sole means of proving dead.

questions.question: Which of the following is NOT a suitable means of isolating a circuit?

options.A: Removing a fuse and locking the distribution board
options.B: Putting insulating tape over the circuit breaker
options.D: Fitting a padlocked circuit breaker lockout

questions.explanation: The isolating device should be switched off or the fuse removed. The switch, circuit breaker or enclosure should then be locked and the key removed. A notice or label should also be posted to warn that someone is working on the circuit or apparatus.

questions.question: Which of the following work procedures on electrical systems will always require a permit-to-work to be issued?
questions.explanation: An electrical permit-to-work should state what circuit or equipment has been made safe, how that has been achieved and what work is to be done. A permit should not, therefore, be used for live working. Such a permit is always required for work on high-voltage systems, but can also be used for low-voltage systems.

questions.question: Optical fibre cable remnants should not be left lying around on site because:

options.A: They can be hot and burn upon contact
options.B: Laser beams still exist in the cut pieces
options.C: They can pierce the skin or eyes

questions.explanation: Fibre fragments can enter the bloodstream and cause infections in the skin or eyes. All fibre waste, particularly small pieces, should be placed in suitable receptacles.

questions.question: Why should the end of an optical fibre cable never be pointed towards your own or anyone else's eyes?

options.A: The beam can transfer a strong electric current
options.B: The colour of the beam is very hypnotic
options.C: The beam can bore a hole through the skin
options.D: The beam can damage the eyes

questions.explanation: Exposure to light sources such as lasers or highly concentrated visible or infrared light beams, associated with the testing or use of optical fibres, can cause damage to the eyes, or even blindness.

questions.question: The use of a multi-lock hasp with the appropriate number of padlocks is a recommended method of safe isolation where:

options.A: Individual circuit breaker locking off devices are not available
options.B: Individual circuit breakers are not identified at the distribution board
options.C: More than one person will be working on circuits supplied from the same distribution board
options.D: You know the health and safety inspector is in the area

questions.explanation: A multi-lock hasp can be used to prevent operation of the isolator until such time that all persons working on the electrical installation have completed their work and removed their padlocks from the hasp.

questions.question: Which of the following procedures should be used when more than one person will be working on circuits supplied from a distribution board which has been switched off?

options.A: The use of a multi-lock hasp on the isolator with a padlock for each operative
options.B: Blowing a horn before the power is switched on again
options.C: Giving each operative a volt stick
options.D: Telling everyone what time the power will be switched on again

questions.explanation: A multi-lock hasp can be used to prevent operation of the isolator until such time that all persons working on the electrical installation have completed their work and removed their padlocks from the hasp.

questions.question: You are on site and you need to dispose of some waste liquid which has oil in it and you are not sure what to do with it. What should you do?

options.A: Dispose of it in a sealed container into the site skip
options.B: Pour it onto the ground, it will soak away
options.C: Take it outside and set light to it
options.D: Ask your supervisor about the correct way to deal with this waste.

questions.explanation: Dealing with hazardous/special waste will include proper storage and segregation before it is taken away by an authorised waste carrier as required by environmental legislation. An oil spillage could also get into the ground or drains, which may also be an offence under environmental law. Burning waste on site is also an offence, under air pollution legislation, and can lead to local complaints.

questions.question: How should you get rid of hazardous/special waste?

options.A: Put it at the bottom of any site skip
options.B: In accordance with the correct site waste rules
options.C: Take it home, they wont want it on site
options.D: Take it to the nearest local authority waste tip

questions.explanation: The Hazardous Waste Regulations (Special Waste Regulations in Scotland) require hazardous/special waste to be properly segregated or otherwise treated, and then recovered or disposed of in an officially approved way.

questions.question: Which of the following is classed as hazardous/special waste?
questions.explanation: Hazardous wastes (special wastes in Scotland) are specified in waste legislation. Fluorescent tubes are included because of their mercury content.

questions.question: Which of the following should be disposed of as hazardous/special waste?
questions.explanation: Hazardous wastes (special wastes in Scotland) are specified in waste legislation. Aerosol sealants are included because they can explode if not recovered or disposed of properly, and they may still contain hazardous solvents.

questions.question: You need to clean up some oil that has leaked from machinery onto the ground. What is the right way to do this?

options.A: Put the oily contaminated soil into the general waste skip
options.B: Put the oily contaminated soil into a suitable container that takes hazardous waste
options.C: Put it under some off-cuts so that the oil cannot be seen
options.D: Wash the oil away with water and detergent

questions.explanation: Oil-contaminated wastes are classified as hazardous/ special waste in waste legislation. The Hazardous Waste Regulations (Special Waste Regulations in Scotland) require such waste to be properly segregated or otherwise treated, and then recovered or disposed of in an approved way. Following the other options would be an offence under waste legislation.

questions.question: Other site workers are complaining that you are generating too much dust. What should you do?

options.A: Tell them you have nearly finished
options.B: Stop work and inform your supervisor
options.C: Ignore them it's none of their business
options.D: Issue the other site workers with dust masks

questions.explanation: Excessive dust may be a health hazard to you and those around you, but even if it is not a health hazard, excessive dust can be a statutory nuisance (under the Environmental Protection Act). Even when it is not a statutory nuisance, it can lead to complaints from neighbours and possible damage to neighbouring property.

questions.question: Who needs to understand relevant environmental risks on a construction site?

options.D: Only the environmental clerk of works

questions.explanation: The actions of everyone on site determine how well the risks to the environment (such as water pollution, or creating a local nuisance) are controlled.

questions.question: Under environmental law, which statement is true?

options.A: Companies and individuals can be prosecuted if they do not follow the law
options.B: Companies can be prosecuted, but not individuals
options.C: It is legal to transport business waste without proper paperwork
options.D: It is legal to disturb protected species habitats

questions.explanation: Most environmental law is enforced against companies, but the regulator in the relevant part of the UK (the Environment Agency, SEPA or NIEA) can also prosecute company officers and even have powers to prosecute employees if they wilfully contribute to environmental harm.

questions.question: Do individuals have any responsibility for sustainability when on site?

options.A: No, it is dealt with by the site manager
options.B: No, it is a matter for the Environment Agency/NIEA/SEPA
options.C: Only on sites where there is asbestos

questions.explanation: Your responsibility is to follow the site and company rules aimed at environmental protection and sustainability, and to help your company to comply with relevant legal requirements, such as the need to segregate waste properly (e.g. so that it can be recovered).

questions.question: Which of the following is NOT best practice from a sustainability point of view?

options.A: Saving materials, fuel, water and energy
options.B: Looking after the people working on or near the site
options.D: Sending unused and waste copper cables to landfill

questions.explanation: Option D would be wasting a valuable natural resource (copper) that could be effectively recovered for later use or recycling. Reusing or recycling copper has less environmental impact than mining and extracting new copper reserves.

questions.question: Which of the following does NOT help sustainability during construction projects?

options.A: Leaving engines and motors running when they are not needed
options.C: Vehicle sharing or using public transport to get to work

questions.explanation: Option A generates local air pollution and carbon dioxide emissions (which contribute to global warming), and also increases the noise nuisance.

questions.question: Which of the following should you do on site in the interest of sustainability?

options.A: Run plant and equipment when they are not needed
options.C: Comply with site instructions on handling waste materials
options.D: Pour waste liquids down a drain off-site

questions.explanation: Your actions will help your company, and others working on site, to achieve more sustainable work practices, such as waste recovery.

questions.question: Which of the following is NOT part of environmentally-friendly construction?

options.A: Creating a dust nuisance to residents in neighbouring properties
options.D: Minimising the amount of waste you create during a job

questions.explanation: Neighbours outside the site are an important part of the wider environment. They may be affected by nuisance (such as noise, dust or even light at night), and they may complain to the client, main contractor or the local enforcing authority. Creating certain types of nuisance is an offence under the Environmental Protection Act.

questions.question: From an environmental point of view, why should materials be reused, where possible?

options.B: A lot of energy and raw materials go into making most construction products
options.C: It makes less mess on site

questions.explanation: Although reducing the amount of waste is the first priority, the re-use of materials can also contribute to effective waste management.

questions.question: Which action will help to minimise waste?

options.A: Only take or open what you need and return or reseal anything left over
options.B: Use new materials/packs at the beginning of each day
options.C: Leave materials unprotected in the rain
options.D: Always order much more than usually required just in case you need it

questions.explanation: The hierarchy for managing waste is to reduce/reuse/recover. Reducing the amount of waste is therefore the first priority.

questions.question: Which of the following is good environmental practice?

options.C: Leaving skips uncovered in wet weather
options.D: Leaving motors running when they are not needed

questions.explanation: This is good practice, since it will help with waste recovery. If the waste is classified as hazardous waste (special waste in Scotland) proper segregation is also a legal requirement.

questions.question: Do individuals have any responsibility for minimising the amount of waste created on site?

options.A: Only if asbestos removal is being carried out
options.B: Yes, everyone on site has this responsibility
options.C: No, it's the responsibility of the client
options.D: Only during site clean-up, at the end of the project

questions.explanation: Your actions will help your company, and others on site, to procure sensibly and to organise the job so that materials and substances are not wasted. Waste reduction is the best option when trying to manage site waste.

questions.question: If you have unused material left, what should you do before you consider putting non-hazardous waste items into a skip?

options.A: Make sure there is a label on it
options.B: Put it in a plastic bag and put it in a skip
options.C: Check whether someone else on your team can make use of it

questions.explanation: Although reducing the amount of waste is the first priority, the reuse of waste materials is much better than disposal, which is the most expensive option and which should be the last resort. Reuse is a better waste management option than recovery.

questions.question: Why should different types of waste be separated on site?

options.A: It will take up less room in the skip
options.B: So the local council can charge Landfill Tax
options.C: So the main contractor can check what's being thrown away
options.D: So waste can be recovered more easily

questions.explanation: This is good practice, since waste recovery can save both energy and materials, compared to creating brand new materials or items. It will also cut the amount of waste that goes to landfill. If the waste is classed as hazardous (special waste in Scotland) then the effective separation of different wastes is a legal requirement.

questions.question: When storing liquids (such as oils, fuels or chemicals) on-site, what must you do?

options.B: Use a transparent container so you can check how much liquid is in it
options.C: Ensure the liquid material is stored safely and securely, and out of the way of site traffic
options.D: Keep the tops off, to prevent pressure from building up

questions.explanation: Any spillage could get into the ground or drains, which is likely to be an offence under environmental legislation.

questions.question: What can help to prevent harm to the environment from oil spillages?

options.A: A supply of water to flush the spill away
options.C: Turning liquid containers upside down so the top can't come off
options.D: Store oils in an area that can catch any spills, such as a bund or a drip tray.

questions.explanation: The use of a bund (fully walled storage area) or a drip tray will help any spillage to be contained in a small area for clear up. Any spillage could get into the ground or drains, which is likely to be an offence under environmental legislation.
